author: funnygiulio
content: It seems to me like they do the same thing

author: .fjl
content: I think it's not quite same. With 7801, the node commits to storing some ranges of history, whereas with the proposed eth/69, it just signals that history below some block is not available.

author: .fjl
content: I see EIP-7801/etha as a solution for retrieving these blocks, which are unavailable in eth.

author: funnygiulio
content: It is the same thing though. I am saying that if you want to signal block ranges you have, you can just use the 7801 handshake. And no, there is no commitment in the EIP. Ypu can change the ranges if you want

author: funnygiulio
content: Also you can express earliestBlock in 7801 too through the handshake

author: funnygiulio
content: This is also why I believe 7801 should be implemented as eth/69 because it can communicate earliestBlock and make everyonw happy. It is an elegant to introduce any pruning heuristic to the network, while what you propose is a domain specific heuristic
